headline: Shalane Flanagan Becomes First U.S. Woman To Win NYC Marathon In 40 Years
short descr: She defeated a Kenyan in the race's women's division.
image_caption(s): Shalane Flanagan celebrates her victory on Sunday in the New York City Marathon.
article: Shalane Flanagan became the first American to win the women‚Äôs division of the New York City Marathon since 1977.Flanagan crossed the finish line on Sunday with an unofficial time of 2 hours, 26 minutes and 53 seconds, the New York Times reported. She defeated three-time defending champion Mary Keitany of Kenya, who came in second.Runner Miki Gorman was the last female American to win the race in 1977.Flanagan first ran the marathon in 2010 and placed second. This was her first time participating in the race since then, ABC 7 reported.Geoffrey Kamworor of Kenya won the men‚Äôs division with a time of 2 hours, 10 minutes and 53 seconds. He edged Wilson Kipsang, also of Kenya, by three seconds.

headline: Rand Paul Suffers 5 Broken Ribs, Bruises In Assault At His Kentucky Home [UPDATED]
short descr: FBI investigating to determine if attack was politically-motivated.
image_caption(s): Rene Albert Boucher allegedly attacked Sen. Rand Paul as the lawmaker was mowing the lawn at his home in Kentucky.
article: A neighbor was arrested after Republican Sen. Rand Paul was attacked at his home in Bowling Green, Kentucky, on Friday afternoon, according to a police report.Officials initially said that Paul suffered minor injuries to his face and a rib, but an aide told the Washington Post on Sunday evening that the senator suffered five broken ribs and bruises to his lungs.Rene Albert Boucher, 59, has been charged with fourth-degree assault with a minor injury, a misdemeanor, according to arrest records. He was being held Saturday afternoon at the Warren County Regional Jail in lieu of a $5,000 bond. No details were released by police on what precipitated the attack.The FBI is ‚Äúinvolved making sure it wasn‚Äôt politically motivated,‚Äù a police spokesman told WBKO-TV. ‚ÄúWe are working with our state and local partners to determine if there was a violation of federal law,‚Äù FBI spokesman David Habich told USA Today. It‚Äôs not known when Paul will be back on the job. ‚ÄúThis type of injury is caused by high-velocity severe force,‚Äù Paul‚Äôs chief of staff Doug Stafford told The Washington Post. ‚ÄúIt is not clear exactly how soon he will return to work, as the pain is considerable as is the difficulty in getting around, including flying.‚ÄùFox News reported that Boucher allegedly attacked the senator and one-time presidential candidate as Paul, 54, was mowing his lawn.A neighbor told WAVE3-TV that the two men had an ongoing feud. Boucher is a registered Democrat.According to the arrest warrant obtained by WKBO and the Bowling Green Daily News, Paul told police that his neighbor walked onto his property and tackled him from behind, forcing him to the ground. Police were called to the home shortly before 3:30 p.m. Friday.The senator‚Äôs injury did not require treatment at a hospital. The arrest warrant said that Boucher admitted to tackling Paul.‚ÄúSenator Paul was blindsided and the victim of an assault,‚Äù his spokeswoman Kelsey Cooper said in a statement. ‚ÄúThe assailant was arrested and it is now a matter for the police. Senator Paul is fine.‚ÄùThe Bowling Green Daily News reported that Boucher is a local anesthesiologist and pain specialist who developed a cloth vest product designed to relieve back pain.State Police Master Trooper Jeremy Hodges told The Associated Press that he couldn‚Äôt reveal any other details of the assault because of security issues. The investigation is ongoing. UPDATE: Story has been updated to describe the severity of Paul‚Äôs injuries.

headline: DNC Chairman Promises To Reform Party's Presidential Nominating Process
short descr: Tom Perez addressed renewed uproar over the DNC's role in the 2016 primary fight.
image_caption(s): DNC Chairman Tom Perez has had to address a lingering divide in the Democratic Party between skeptical progressives and more establishment-minded party figures.
article: In a Saturday blogpost, Democratic National Committee chairman Tom Perez vowed to enact reforms to the party‚Äôs presidential nominating process aimed at ensuring that ‚Äúthe new DNC will work to rebuild trust with the people we represent.‚ÄùPerez‚Äôs column on Medium, entitled ‚ÄúMaking 2020 Transparent,‚Äù was a response to revelations by former interim DNC chairwoman Donna Brazile last week that in a signed agreement the committee had effectively surrendered its independence to Hillary Clinton‚Äôs campaign in August 2015 ‚Äï months before 2016 presidential primary voters went to the polls. Many supporters of Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) interpreted the news as confirmation that the party had treated him unfairly.‚ÄúI am more committed than ever before to restoring voters‚Äô faith in our democratic process because even the perception of impartiality or an unfair advantage undermines our ability to win,‚Äù Perez said. ‚ÄúThat is unacceptable.‚Äù‚ÄúAfter listening to Democrats from every wing of our party, I‚Äôve developed a series of concrete reforms to put our principles into action and guarantee that under my watch, the new DNC will work to rebuild trust with the people we represent,‚Äù he said.The ‚Äúprinciples‚Äù Perez plans to employ include deciding the presidential primary debate schedule well before voting in the contests begins and making transparent to the public any joint fundraising agreements the DNC makes.He also promised to support the work of the Unity Reform Commission, a panel formed in July 2016 as a compromise with delegates who backed Sanders at the Democratic National Convention.‚ÄúWe will work with the Unity Reform Commission to implement their collective recommendations for meaningful change in our party,‚Äù Perez said.The commission is due to recommend reforms to the nominating process by January 2018. The 21-member panel is discussing plans to make the party‚Äôs budget more transparent, diminish the role of so-called superdelegates in the nominating process, and make it easier for independents and new voters to participate in Democratic primaries and caucuses.Nomiki Konst, one of eight Sanders appointees on the commission, expressed disappointment that Perez did not explicitly address DNC budget transparency and prohibiting the committee‚Äôs voting members from having business with the organization or other conflicts of interest that could jade their ability to act impartially.‚ÄúAt this point, with barely any funds, compromised integrity and low trust, Chairman Perez needs to prove above and beyond that he‚Äôs willing to reform this party,‚Äù Konst said in a text message to HuffPost. ‚ÄúMake it transparent, accountable, inclusive and eliminate conflicts of interest that have burdened it.‚Äù

headline: Kris Jenner Prank Shopping With Ellen In Her Ear Is Pure Hilarity
short descr: It's Kris Jenner like you've never seen her before.
image_caption(s): Kris Jenner, who was wearing an earpiece, is seen laughing on cue while shopping at a 99-cent store.
article: After E! network inked a $150 million deal to renew ‚ÄúKeeping Up With The Kardashians,‚Äù the 99-cent store would seem the last place you‚Äôd find family matriarch Kris Kenner.But that‚Äôs exactly where ‚ÄúThe Ellen DeGeneres Show‚Äù sent the reality TV star as part of the talk show‚Äôs hidden earpiece series, Ellen‚Äôs Show Me More Show, on Friday and the results couldn‚Äôt have been funnier.The 62-year-old momager, with Ellen feeding directions into her ear, was instructed to eat and wear unpaid merchandise, laugh hysterically on cue, demonstrate her finger-dancing skills, and confess that she buys razors to shave her back to an unsuspecting cashier.As the video shows, it didn‚Äôt take long for her to pull off a pretty convincing celebrity breakdown.‚ÄúHi, I‚Äôm Kris Jenner, I‚Äôm a big celebrity,‚Äù she first tells the cashier, who beams with delight at the introduction. ‚ÄúBefore I check out, I have a couple questions.‚ÄùJenner is then instructed to question the prices on a coconut and a pack of razors ‚Äï during which she is forced to reveal her hairy secret ‚Äï and also ask how much wine a plastic bucket can hold.But it was her last secret shared that left the cashier with a particularly nervous expression on her face.‚ÄúMommy‚Äôs broke,‚Äù she tells the cashier in a whisper. ‚ÄúBut you know what, too blessed to be stressed.‚Äù‚ÄúAnd laugh really hard,‚Äù Ellen instructs her, prompting Jenner to roll her head back and cackle loudly. ‚ÄúJust keep laughing, just keep laughing, yes!‚ÄùBehind her, a man impatiently waits to pay for several items and gives her a glare.He may not have been amused, but Ellen‚Äôs audience sure was.‚ÄúI look like a lunatic!‚Äù Jenner proclaimed after finally informing the cashier that it was all just a stunt ‚Äï but one worthy of a daytime Emmy, if you ask us.

headline: Jeff Sessions Needs To Be 'Precise,' 'Accurate' About Trump's Campaign And Russia: Feinstein
short descr: Court documents cast doubt on the attorney general's previous testimony that he had no knowledge of communication between the Trump campaign and Moscow.
image_caption(s): The Senate Judiciary Committee's ranking Democrat, Dianne Feinstein of California, wants Attorney General Jeff Sessions to testify again before the committee about interactions between the Trump campaign and Russian officials.
article: WASHINGTON ‚Äï The top Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee said on Sunday she wants Attorney General Jeff Sessions to testify again before the panel to clarify past claims that he was unaware of any communication between members of Donald Trump‚Äôs presidential campaign and Russian officials. Sessions has already testified before the committee twice under oath ‚Äï during his confirmation hearing in January and during a routine oversight hearing last month ‚Äï that he was unaware of communications between the Trump team and Russia. But according to recently unsealed court documents, former Trump campaign foreign policy adviser George Papadopoulos spoke multiple times with Russians about setting up a meeting between then-presidential candidate Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin. And Papadopoulos, according to the documents. described his efforts during a meeting on March 31, 2016, that included Trump and Sessions.Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) said on CNN she plans to discuss summoning Sessions back before the Judiciary Committee with the panel‚Äôs chairman, Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa). She declined to say whether she believed Sessions intentionally misled the committee in the past ‚Äï but said the attorney general should focus on getting his facts straight.‚ÄúMaybe he has a faulty memory. So, there are a lot of excuses one can make.‚Äù Feinstein said. ‚ÄúBut at this stage, he‚Äôs got to narrow his recollections. When he comes before the committee again, he has to be precise, and it has to be accurate,‚Äù she said.Since the unsealing on Monday of the court documents concerning Papadopoulos ‚Äï who has pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI about his contacts with Russian officials during the campaign ‚Äï Democrats on the Judiciary Committee have been pushing for Sessions to explain the discrepancy between the information in them and his testimony.The attorney general has been given the chance to clarify past testimony, ‚Äúyet he only continued to mislead,‚Äù Sen. Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.) said in a statement. ‚ÄúHe now needs to come back before the committee, in person, under oath, to explain why he cannot seem to provide truthful, complete answers to these important and relevant questions.‚Äù ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think he told me the truth,‚Äù Sen. Al Franken (D-Minn.) told ABC late last week. ‚ÄúI think that on different occasions he either has a terrible memory or he is deliberately not telling me the truth.‚ÄùLawmakers‚Äô frustration with Sessions may be gaining bipartisan traction.‚ÄúThis is getting a bit old with Jeff Sessions,‚Äù Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) told Fox News‚Äô Chris Wallace on Sunday. ‚ÄúHe probably should come back and answer the question, yet again, ‚ÄòDid you know anything about an effort by the Trump campaign to meet with Russia?‚Äô‚ÄùThis article has been updated with Graham‚Äôs comment.

headline: Mueller Has Enough Evidence to Charge Mike Flynn, Trump's Former National Security Adviser: Report
short descr: Flynn would be the first former Trump administration official to face charges in the investigation.
image_caption(s): Flynn (right), with then-GOP presidential nominee Trump at a campaign stop in 2016.
article: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Special Counsel Robert Mueller has collected sufficient evidence to charge Michael Flynn, U.S. President Donald Trump‚Äôs former national security adviser, and his son, NBC News reported on Sunday, citing multiple sources familiar with the investigation.NBC News said Mueller‚Äôs team is looking at possible money laundering charges, lying to federal agents, and Flynn‚Äôs role in a possible plan to remove an opponent of the Turkish president from the United States in exchange for millions of dollars. Mueller is increasing pressure on Flynn following his indictment of Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort, NBC News said.Flynn served 24 days as Trump‚Äôs national security adviser but was fired after it was discovered he had misrepresented his contacts with a Russian diplomat to Vice President Michael Pence.The NBC report said that lawyers for Flynn and his son, Michael G. Flynn, who worked with his father, declined to comment as did Mueller‚Äôs office.Reuters was not immediately able to confirm the report.(Reporting by Howard Schneider; Editing by Lisa Shumaker)

headline: Trump‚Äôs Exit From Anti-Corruption Pact Helps Big Oil Hide How Much It Pays In US Taxes
short descr: The withdrawal comes as House Republicans push a tax bill packed with corporate welfare for fossil fuel companies.
image_caption(s): Speaker of the House Paul Ryan looks on as President Donald Trump speaks about tax reform legislation in the Cabinet Room at the White House on Nov. 2, 2017 in Washington.
article: The Trump administration has pulled out of a global deal to combat corruption in the fossil fuel industry, a move critics said could help oil companies keep hidden how much they pay in U.S. taxes. The Department of the Interior announced the decision on Thursday in a letter to withdraw immediately from the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI), which compels oil, gas and mining companies to disclose payments to governments worldwide. The United Kingdom, Canada and many European Union nations already require such disclosures, and the 15-year-old initiative is credited with establishing the foundation for reform in countries such as Ghana and the Democratic Republic of Congo. But the U.S., which joined in 2014, only finalized rules calling for disclosures in July 2016, under the Dodd-Frank reform law passed during the Great Recession. In February, Trump signed a congressional resolution to repeal the Securities and Exchange Commission regulation, essentially leaving the U.S. without a tool to enforce EITI standards. The rule would have required companies to file annual reports revealing how much they paid in taxes, royalties, licensing fees and other payments. Some firms, including BHP Billiton and Houston-based Kosmos Energy, voluntarily released tax data in recent years. The country‚Äôs top three oil companies ‚Äï Exxon Mobil Corp., Chevron Corporation and ConocoPhillips Co. ‚Äï did not. ‚ÄúThey want to continue operating in the murky and opaque world that Dodd-Frank was intended to change,‚Äù Daniel Kaufmann, an economist who studies corruption and serves on the global EITI board, told HuffPost by phone on Friday. ‚ÄúEven Russian companies are all disclosing. So the rest of the world, and the rest of the oil companies, have moved ahead.‚Äù‚ÄúThe U.S. ones refuse to change their old habits of operating in opacity,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs means tax avoidance, obviously, and it raises the risk of more corrupt deals.‚Äù The secrecy underscores the generous subsidies and tax credits afforded to the oil and gas industry. Nearly half of all untapped oil reserves in the U.S. would be unprofitable without subsidies, a study published last month in the journal Nature found. Exxon Mobil alone received $12.8 billion in subsidies and paid a tax rate of 13.6 percent over the past eight years, according to a report by the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy. (The report did not calculate data for Chevron or ConocoPhillips.) For comparison, nurses and appraisers earning on average $60,000 per year pay an individual tax rate of about 15 percent.‚ÄúIf people see that Chevron and Exxon are making bank, making hand over fist extracting resources from the U.S. and not paying their fair share, people would have a problem with that,‚Äù Jana Morgan, director of the Publish What You Pay coalition that supports the EITI initiative, told HuffPost. ‚ÄúSo they want to keep it secret.‚Äù The move came the same day House Republicans introduced a tax bill that preserves generous subsidies and tax credits for fossil fuel companies, and eliminates incentives to buy electric vehicles or use renewable energy. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre spending so much time in the U.S. focusing on the cost of health care and taking away money from Planned Parenthood and social welfare,‚Äù Morgan said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre so focused on getting rid of those but we don‚Äôt want to get rid of corporate welfare.‚ÄùIn a statement to HuffPost, Chevron spokeswoman Melissa Ritchie said the company has been working to meet EITI standards. ‚ÄúChevron spent a significant amount of time preparing and reconciling USEITI report data,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúbut not payments to the IRS, given the confidential nature of IRS data.‚Äù Exxon Mobil spokesman Scott Silvestri directed HuffPost to a January op-ed published in The Dallas Morning News that ‚Äúfocuses on our commitment to transparency initiatives.‚Äù ConocoPhillips did not return a call requesting comment on Friday. The American Petroleum Institute, the industry group that lobbied the Trump administration and Republican lawmakers to overturn the SEC disclosure rule, said it would ‚Äúcontinue working with the U.S. Department of Interior in reporting revenues and disbursements and with the U.S. State Department to drive global transparency.‚Äù On a broader level, the decision to stop participating in the EITI echoes President Donald Trump‚Äôs withdrawal from the Paris climate accord. As with EITI, the administration stopped implementing policies to meet the pact‚Äôs standards before formally pulling out. ‚ÄúThe decision to pull out was of greater symbolic significance than anything else,‚Äù Matthew Stephenson, a Harvard Law School professor who writes a blog about corruption, told HuffPost by phone on Friday. ‚ÄúIt indicated the U.S. no longer had an interest in working with, let alone leading, the international community on this issue.‚Äù

headline: Netflix Takes No Action Against Danny Masterson Despite Multiple Rape Accusations
short descr: Netflix says it's "aware" of the investigation and "will respond if developments occur."
image_caption(s): Actor Danny Masterson has been accused of rape by four women. Netflix says it is taking a wait-and-see approach to the investigation.
article: One day after a HuffPost report revealed that actor Danny Masterson is the subject of a criminal investigation into allegations of rape by four women, Netflix, which produces and airs the program he co-stars on, ‚ÄúThe Ranch,‚Äù has told HuffPost it isn‚Äôt taking any action against him.‚ÄúWe are aware of the allegations and the subsequent investigation, and will respond if developments occur,‚Äù a Netflix spokesman said in a statement emailed to HuffPost.Four women have accused Masterson of violently raping them in the early 2000s. One year ago, the Los Angeles Police Department opened an investigation into the claims and found the evidence compelling enough to refer the case to the Los Angeles County district attorney. The investigation has been overseen by one of the top prosecutors in the office, Reinhold Mueller.One of Masterson‚Äôs accusers initially filed an LAPD report in 2004 saying that she was raped in 2003 while she was ‚Äúpassed out‚Äù and that, when she awoke and realized Masterson was raping her, she struggled with him until he choked her and she passed out again. The case was not referred to the district attorney at the time after more than 50 members of the Church of Scientology, which both Masterson and his accuser belonged to, submitted affidavits to the LAPD denying the woman‚Äôs account. The tactic is a common one for the organization, which is known for using fear and intimidation in order to silence anyone perceived as attacking Scientology.Two of Masterson‚Äôs accusers initially reported being raped directly to the Church of Scientology. Scientology rules say that members of the church must never report a Scientologist to law enforcement. The punishment would be immediate expulsion from the church, which would include family and friends being ordered not to associate with or speak to the banished member.HuffPost was the first to reveal that there is a fourth accuser who has been interviewed by the district attorney‚Äôs office. Additional information about that accuser is not available.The evidence that the district attorney has amassed as part of this case has been described as ‚Äúcompelling‚Äù and ‚Äúoverwhelming‚Äù by multiple sources and includes audiotapes, emails sent to and from Scientology officers at the time the alleged rapes happened, forensic computer evidence and a threatening handwritten letter Masterson sent to one of the alleged victims.HuffPost was the first to report that there were concerns in the district attorney‚Äôs office that the investigation had inexplicably stalled despite the substantial evidence.A spokesman for the Los Angeles County District Attorney‚Äôs Office has declined to comment on the case.Netflix announced that ‚ÄúThe Ranch: Part 4‚Äù would premiere on its website in December. The company made the announcement on Oct. 17, seven months after news of the LAPD investigation was made public by journalist Tony Ortega and subsequently reported by multiple news outlets.According to a source familiar with ‚ÄúThe Ranch‚Äù production schedule, Masterson and co-star Ashton Kutcher are in the process of filming Part 5 of ‚ÄúThe Ranch.‚ÄùTwo days after a BuzzFeed report that detailed a sexual misconduct allegation against actor and producer Kevin Spacey by actor Anthony Rapp, Netflix suspended filming of Spacey‚Äôs ‚ÄúHouse of Cards‚Äù series. It‚Äôs unclear why it hasn‚Äôt made a similar decision when Masterson is the subject of a years-long law enforcement investigation involving four allegations of rape.A Netflix spokesman has not immediately replied to follow-up questions sent after its statement about not taking action against Masterson.UPDATE: Nov. 7 ‚Äï The Church of Scientology provided a statement to HuffPost late Monday, saying that it ‚Äúhas no practice or policy forbidding the reporting of criminal wrongdoing allegedly committed by Scientologists or anyone else, nor does the Church expel, let alone punish, members who report crimes.‚ÄùFollow Yashar ‚Äî or send him a tip ‚Äî on Twitter: @yashar

headline: Paul Manafort Offers Up Trump Tower Apartment In Bid To Get Off House Arrest
short descr: Despite having three passports, his lawyers said Manafort is no "Jason Bourne."
image_caption(s): Paul Manafort walks out of a federal courthouse in Washington after a Nov. 2 hearing.
article: WASHINGTON ‚Äï Attorneys for former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort told a federal judge on Saturday that he‚Äôs not ‚Äúakin to a 68-year-old ‚ÄòJason Bourne‚Äô character‚Äù despite his possession of three passports.Manafort is set to appear in court again on Monday morning for a hearing on the conditions of his release following his arrest last week on 12 federal counts, including conspiracy and money laundering. He and his business associate Rick Gates have pleaded not guilty to the charges brought forward by special counsel Robert Mueller, who is investigating Russian interference in the 2016 election. U.S. District Judge Amy Berman Jackson said at Manafort‚Äôs second court hearing on Thursday that she was concerned that he posed a flight risk. In a court filing on Saturday, Manafort‚Äôs lawyers assured the judge that the reason he had three passports was ‚Äúmundane‚Äù: He has a primary passport, a second passport to submit with visa applications to certain foreign countries, and a third that he applied for after he lost his primary passport, which he later found.Manafort‚Äôs ‚Äúfrequent flyer status,‚Äù lawyer Kevin Downing wrote, ‚Äúshould not be over-emphasized to show a potential risk of flight when a person‚Äôs job requires extensive travel.‚Äù He said that Manafort was just a ‚Äúsuccessful domestic and international political consultant‚Äù who ‚Äútraveled frequently and represented businessmen, political parties, and commercial interests around the world,‚Äù activities that were ‚Äúcompletely‚Äù legal.‚ÄúIt would be odd, indeed, if he did not frequently travel, both domestically and abroad, given his clientele and the nature of his business,‚Äù Downing wrote.He also noted that Manafort has been married for almost 40 years and has two daughters and two grandchildren in the U.S. He said that his client‚Äôs primary assets are also in the United States. One of the charges that Manafort is facing relates to his alleged failure to register under the Foreign Agents Registration Act, which requires lobbyists to disclose when they‚Äôre working on behalf of a foreign principal. Downing, not incorrectly, said that particular charge was ‚Äúrarely pursued (or successfully prosecuted) in a criminal case.‚ÄùManafort is currently on house arrest under electronic monitoring and a $10 million unsecured bond. He‚Äôs seeking less onerous conditions of release. To guarantee his future court appearances, his attorney said Manafort would be willing to pledge a $3 million Trump Tower apartment in New York City, another $3.5 million home in New York, a $1.5 million home in Palm Beach, Florida, and a ‚Äúcombination of life insurance policies held in trust and/or in his or his wife‚Äôs name‚Äù and valued at approximately $4.5 million ‚Äï for a total of more than $12 million.Although Manafort has not yet reached an agreement with prosecutors over the conditions of his release, his lawyers wrote that he would agree to limit his travel to Florida, Virginia, New York and Washington, D.C. Prosecutors with Mueller‚Äôs office are expected to file their response to the Manafort filing on Sunday.On Thursday, Jackson seemed open to lifting Manafort‚Äôs house arrest but skeptical of removing his electronic monitoring.Ryan Reilly is HuffPost‚Äôs senior justice reporter, covering criminal justice, federal law enforcement and legal affairs. headline: Kelly Clarkson Felt 'Suppressed,' Says Top Country Star's Career Changed When He Came Out
authors: Pollo Del Mar , ContributorDrag queen on the SF social, political, editorial and fundrais...
short descr: ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs an amazing singer, an amazing performer, but nobody could get past [his being gay].‚Äù
image_caption(s): Kelly Clarkson says it has taken 15 years to be ‚Äúallowed‚Äù to release new album Meaning of Life.
article: Kelly Clarkson has scored a trio of Grammys, more than 100 cumulative No. 1 singles on various Billboard charts and become an icon in the music industry. Yet from the beginning, the first-ever American Idol says, record labels and executives have tried to define who she is as both a person and musician. ‚ÄúHonestly, you can look at my previous records and you can hear a suppressed individual,‚Äù Clarkson told Party Foul Radio with Pollo & Pearl. ‚ÄúI just constantly felt pushed into a box.‚ÄùThroughout her career, Clarkson‚Äôs struggle for creative liberation has been tabloid fodder. She dropped Idol‚Äôs 19 Management team, then went toe-to-toe with former industry giant Clive Davis to gain greater freedom in her sound. Sometimes there were victories, she said; other times, she had to ‚Äúcompromise.‚ÄùA deciding factor in her need to ‚Äúbend‚Äù to corporate pressure was the band and team supporting her. Had she pushed back too much, she told listeners of Podomatic‚Äôs No. 1 LGBTQ podcast, the label would ‚Äúsit on‚Äù her music and prevent touring, presenting a financial burden for those with whom she has worked with for nearly a decade.‚ÄúYou carry this weight on you to keep everyone afloat,‚Äù Clarkson confessed. ‚ÄúI feel everything. It‚Äôs annoying.‚ÄùThe superstar recalled a conversation years ago with her equally famous mother-in-law Reba McIntyre. Though conceding she, too, feels the burden of celebrity, the country music legend told Clarkson: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre just a different type of personality. You take on everything.‚Äù Fortunately, it appears Clarkson‚Äôs ‚Äúdevastating‚Äù battle for artistic authenticity is behind her. Now signed to Atlantic Records, she dropped eighth album Meaning of Life Oct. 27. Not only does she feel it‚Äôs her best work to date, it‚Äôs also proven to be a relief.‚ÄúWhen you are that type of person ‚Äì an emotional person, in a good way ‚Äì it‚Äôs really wonderful to be part of a project that‚Äôs 100-percent you, 100-percent your personality and no one is holding you back,‚Äù Clarkson said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre supporting you being you,‚Äù she said of her experience with Atlantic. ‚ÄúFifteen years later, this is my first time experiencing that!‚ÄùAtlantic‚Äôs belief in both Clarkson ‚Äì whose eleven Top 10 hits, three No. 1 singles and trio of chart-topping albums make her one of the industry‚Äôs most bankable stars ‚Äì and the album are obvious. Of 14 tracks on Meaning of Life, Clarkson co-wrote four. The rest bear the sonic stamp of a veritable music industry who‚Äôs who. WATCH: Pollo Del Mar‚Äôs Track-By-Track Review of Meaning of LifeLead single ‚ÄúLove So Soft‚Äù alone combines powerhouses Mozella (Miley Cyrus‚Äô ‚ÄúWrecking Ball‚Äù), Priscilla Renea (co-writer of Fifth Harmony‚Äôs ‚ÄúWorth It‚Äù) and Jesse Shatkin (Sia‚Äôs ‚ÄúAlive‚Äù). Elsewhere are the fingerprints of hip-hop producers The Monarchs (Nicki Minaj, Justin Bieber), Grammy nominee Mick Schultz (Jeremih‚Äôs ‚ÄúBirthday Sex‚Äù) and Greg Kurstin, the Grammy-winning genius behind Adele‚Äôs ‚ÄúHello.‚ÄùSaying she previously has ‚Äúnever worked with people who would allow‚Äù an album like Meaning of Life, the Texan indicated the reasons stemmed largely from industry decisions on what kind of artist she should be. However, in the interview ‚Äï recorded Oct. 11, National Coming Out Day ‚Äì Clarkson related the story of Nashville-based songwriter Shane McAnally, whose sexual identity altered his path to stardom.‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a phenomenal writer; he‚Äôs had like a bajillion No. 1s now,‚Äù Clarkson pointed out. ‚ÄúBack in the day, when he was someone‚Äôs assistant somewhere, shuffling coffee around, he got, ‚ÄòYou can‚Äôt make it as a country singer if they know you‚Äôre gay.‚Äô‚ÄùIn 1999, McAnally signed to Curb Records. After marginal success as a solo artist, he relocated to Los Angeles, where he came out. When he sought to resume his career in country music, though, the stigma of being a gay artist was off-putting to many. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs changing now,‚Äù Clarkson said, but at the time being out was not acceptable in country music.‚ÄúHe had to go a different way, and in the end, it‚Äôs worked out for him,‚Äù said Clarkson of McAnally, who channeled his considerable talents into writing hits for other.Now Shane McAnally is a multiple-time Grammy and Academy of Country Music Award-winner who has written No. 1 country singles for everyone from Kenny Chesney and Keith Urban to Miranda Lambert and former Hootie & The Blowfish frontman Darius Rucker.He was named the 2014 ACM Songwriter of the Year and won two Grammys for work on Kacey Musgraves‚Äô breakthrough Same Trailer Different Park. He appears on-track for another blockbuster year as Sam Hunt‚Äôs ‚ÄúBody Like a Back Road,‚Äù written by McAnally, crossed into the Top 10 at pop radio and is the biggest country single of 2017. He is presently at work on a Broadway musical based on the TV classic ‚ÄúHee Haw.‚Äù‚ÄúIt‚Äôs insane all the stuff he‚Äôs accomplishing,‚Äù Clarkson gushed about the man who contributed two songs to her chart-topping 2015 album Piece By Piece.‚ÄúBut what‚Äôs sad about that for me ‚Äì as a friend who‚Äôs watching ‚Äì is he could have sang all that shit himself,‚Äù she lamented. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs an amazing singer, an amazing performer, but nobody could get past [his being gay].‚ÄùLISTEN: Party Foul Radio Interviews Kelly Clarkson

headline: Experts Urge Trump: 'Stick To The Script' In Asia, Don't Provoke North Korea
short descr: Washington and Pyongyang have engaged in an escalating war of words.
image_caption(s): President Donald Trump's taunts and insults directed at North Korean leader Kim Jong Un ‚Äúcreate an incentive for the North Koreans to stage provocations to show him up,‚Äù a nuclear nonproliferation expert said.
article: As President Donald Trump makes his journey to Asia for a 12-day, five-country trip, international security experts are urging him to ‚Äústick to the script‚Äù and avoid making incendiary comments while discussing North Korea.The ‚ÄúAmerica first‚Äù leader has engaged in an escalating war of words with North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un in recent months. In September, Trump threatened to ‚Äútotally destroy‚Äù the rogue nation, which is home to an estimated 25 million people, if provoked.Pyongyang has made significant advancements to its internationally condemned nuclear program this year and has repeatedly claimed that it is capable of striking the U.S. mainland with a nuclear-tipped intercontinental ballistic missile. Kim‚Äôs regime is expected to be a key topic of discussion during Trump‚Äôs meetings in China, South Korea and Japan.As tensions rise, experts fear Trump‚Äôs response to the situation is only fanning the flames, not dousing the fire.‚ÄúTrumpian rhetoric to ‚Äòtotally destroy‚Äô North Korea is not helpful at a time when, alarmingly, the likelihood of all-out war on the Korean Peninsula has moved from remotely possible to almost palpable,‚Äù William Choong and Alexander Neill, senior fellows at the International Institute for Strategic Studies, wrote in a report published Friday.‚ÄúIt is critically important for Asia-Pacific security that Trump does not fly off the handle,‚Äù they warned.On Thursday, national security adviser H.R. McMaster told reporters Trump is unlikely to moderate his remarks overseas.‚ÄúThe president will use whatever language he wants to use, obviously,‚Äù McMaster said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think the president really modulates his language. I mean, have you noticed him do that? He has been very clear about that.‚ÄùThis is hardly surprising to Catherine Dill, a defense analyst at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies, but it is ‚Äúabsolutely concerning.‚Äù‚ÄúIn my view, with North Korea ‚Äï and to some degree, also with [U.S.] allies in the region ‚Äï there is a real risk of miscalculation and unintended escalation. A lot of that could occur because of sloppy rhetoric,‚Äù she said.If Trump makes bellicose comments about Pyongyang during his travels through Asia, Dill worries possible reactions from the North Korean regime could range from moderate, such as a short-range missile test, to severe, like a longer-range missile launch that overflies Japan.She‚Äôs not optimistic that Trump‚Äôs visit to Asia will serve to improve relations with the North Korean regime. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt really have any hopes,‚Äù she said with a laugh. ‚ÄúI think the best possible outcome is that it doesn‚Äôt lead to war.‚ÄùOn the other hand, Dill sees the trip as an opportunity for Trump to ‚Äúreassure Japan and South Korea, and also try to have a measured, constructive conversation with China.‚ÄùDue to their proximity to North Korea, American allies Tokyo and Seoul are especially vulnerable to a potential retaliatory attack by Pyongyang if it felt threatened or provoked. Trump has aggressively pressured Beijing to leverage its influence over the hermit kingdom to curb its nuclear ambitions.Jeffrey Lewis, director of Middlebury‚Äôs East Asia Nonproliferation Program, also frets that more hostile statements or tweets from Trump about North Korea could exacerbate an already-tense standoff between Washington and Pyongyang. The president‚Äôs taunts and derogatory nicknames for Kim, such as ‚ÄúLittle Rocket Man‚Äù and other insults, ‚Äúcreate an incentive for the North Koreans to stage provocations to show him up,‚Äù said Lewis. If the situation deteriorates into an acute crisis, such aggravating remarks from Trump could give the impression that a military strike is imminent, he added. ‚ÄúIf that happens, my belief is the North Koreans would use their nuclear weapons first, in order to try to repel an invasion.‚ÄùLewis does not anticipate a nuclear test or missile launch by North Korea during Trump‚Äôs Asia trip but notes that ‚Äúit‚Äôs possible they‚Äôll try to upstage [Trump]‚Äù with such a provocation as a form of political messaging.‚Äú[North Korea] could totally do that. That is the kind of thing that they would do,‚Äù but they tend to scale back their missile tests during the colder months, he explained. The regime has timed several tests to coincide with politically significant events, including Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe‚Äôs visit to America and the eve of Independence Day in the U.S.As to whether Trump‚Äôs inflammatory rhetoric would be more damaging if issued while he‚Äôs in Asia rather than back in Washington, Lewis said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all bad.‚Äù He likened the scenarios to choosing ‚Äúbetween plague and cholera.‚Äù

headline: Florida Woman Arrested For Allegedly Riding A Horse While Drunk
short descr: "She not only put herself and the horse in danger, but also anyone who was driving on the road," local sheriff Grady Judd said.
image_caption(s): Donna Byrne was arrested for allegedly being drunk while riding a horse.
article: Police in Florida arrested a 53-year-old woman on Thursday afternoon for allegedly riding a horse while drunk.Donna Byrne appeared confused and smelled strongly of alcohol when Polk County Sheriff‚Äôs Office deputies pulled her over on a busy Lakeland road just after 1:30 p.m., according to multiple reports. She was found to be more than twice the legal breath-alcohol limit for driving.‚ÄúMs. Byrne was obviously not in any condition to be on the road,‚Äù Sheriff Grady Judd said via a statement. ‚ÄúShe not only put herself and the horse in danger, but also anyone who was driving on the road, which is typically very busy.‚ÄùPolice charged Byrne with driving under the influence and animal neglect.Deputies transported her horse, named Bo Duke, to Polk County Sheriff‚Äôs Animal Control livestock facility. The animal is likely to be eventually returned to Byrne, per the Orlando Sentinel.

headline: The Making Of 'Alias Grace,' A Margaret Atwood True-Crime Mystery
short descr: How "American Psycho" director Mary Harron brought a harrowing story of female servitude to Netflix.
image_caption(s): Margaret Atwood in a cameo appearance in "Alias Grace."
article: If ‚ÄúThe Handmaid‚Äôs Tale‚Äù is where we‚Äôre going, ‚ÄúAlias Grace‚Äù is where we came from.So says Sarah Polley, the writer and producer behind the new Netflix adaptation of Margaret Atwood‚Äôs 1996 novel. The work of historical fiction revolves around the titular Grace Marks, a 19th-century servant accused of brutally murdering the master of her household and his mistress, a fellow housekeeper, with the help of a stablehand. The real-life crime rocked Upper Canada in 1843, hurling the Victorian community into a salacious trial that amounted to a life sentence for Marks and a hanging for her accomplice. After 30 years in prison, Grace was eventually pardoned, but her exoneration was a mere consolation prize after decades of living as a notorious woman.‚ÄúMurderess is a strong word to have attached to you,‚Äù Marks says in Atwood‚Äôs book. ‚ÄúIt has a smell to it, that word ‚Äï musky and oppressive, like dead flowers in a vase. Sometimes at night I whisper it over to myself: Murderess, murderess. It rustles, like a taffeta skirt across the floor.‚ÄùPolley brought the beloved Atwoodian tale to life with the help of acclaimed ‚ÄúAmerican Psycho‚Äù director Mary Harron. Together, they created a six-episode miniseries that places Marks, expertly played by Sarah Gadon, as its center of gravity. She at times appears powerless, the product of poverty and neglect forced into an unforgiving life of servitude, and at other times as a careless and deliberate enigma, driven by an internal force we‚Äôve yet to understand. Is she a cold-blooded killer, or a unduly scorned castaway?Both Atwood and the Polley-Harron adaptation team shy away from answering that question. Instead, the new Netflix series is at its best when it sinks into the historic details that complicate Marks‚Äô narrative. In the show‚Äôs meticulously crafted world, an echo of real 19th-century horrors, lower-class women are relegated to sexual prey, cast as the constant targets of unwanted advances and the unfortunate recipients of botched abortions. Indeed, if ‚ÄúHandmaid‚Äôs Tale‚Äù is the fundamentalist dystopia of our future, ‚ÄúAlias Grace‚Äù makes it its mission to paint a clear picture of the overlooked history that would make Gilead possible.We spoke to Harron ahead of the show‚Äôs premiere on Nov. 3. and she echoed Polley‚Äôs unnerving parallel between both hair-raising Atwood adaptations, and explained what it was like bringing the story of Grace Marks to life.What initially drew you to the adaptation of Alias Grace? Well, I hadn‚Äôt read the novel. I knew nothing about the story going in, I had no preconceptions about it. But it‚Äôs such a fantastic plot. You get totally drawn into this world. I‚Äôve always loved ambiguity and mystery, and also a female character who suffers a lot but isn‚Äôt conventionally, like, ‚ÄúOh, poor Grace.‚Äù She‚Äôs very complicated. Is she good? Is she bad? Have the things she‚Äôs suffered turned her into a murderer? All of these things. I was very drawn into the world right away.Were you a Margaret Atwood fan before this?Yeah, I‚Äôm Canadian, so of course. I was also at university in the ‚Äô70s when her first novels started coming out. Or, at least, that‚Äôs when I started discovering them. She had a big impact on feminism at the point ‚Äï of that generation. I was very affected by the stories that she was telling. But I hadn‚Äôt read her most recent stuff. So it was a real revelation. [Alias Grace] is actually my favorite Margaret Atwood novel now.The novel is based on a real crime that happened in Canada in the 1840s. Were you aware of the story of Grace Marks at all?I read a couple reviews of [Atwood‚Äôs] book when it came out, but I had never heard of [Marks]. It was very mysterious. I‚Äôve done a lot of period drama ‚Äï my first film [‚ÄúI Shot Andy Warhol‚Äù] was the 1960s, ‚ÄúBettie Page‚Äù was the 1950s, ‚ÄúAmerican Psycho‚Äù was the 1980s. I studied literature at university ‚Äï I‚Äôm pretty steeped in the Victorian novel ‚Äï so I always wanted to do a period drama like this. This is a very interesting take on a 19th-century story.The story revolves around perhaps one of the most enigmatic characters Margaret Atwood ever wrote. If you could give your own character description of Grace Marks, what would it be?This is important: She‚Äôs a young girl, Protestant, from Northern Ireland. She‚Äôs very competent and capable and bright. She‚Äôs the sort of person who could have run a corporation, but she‚Äôs born into a world of incredible poverty and oppression, and she suffers greatly. She‚Äôs quite puritanical, like a lot of Northern Irish Protestants. I can say that, because my family‚Äôs from there. She has love in her heart, but the question is: With all her sufferings, did they make her a better person or a worse person? With all the terrible things that she has had to go through, which way did they turn her in the end? I had this conversation with Margaret Atwood. People think that suffering makes you noble, but not always. Sometimes, a lot of suffering can turn you. It can make you vindictive and murderess. You don‚Äôt know. Yes, that‚Äôs certainly one of the intriguing aspects of the way Atwood wrote the character. You don‚Äôt necessarily know if Grace is the protagonist or the antagonist of the story. And that doesn‚Äôt really seem to be the point. There‚Äôs not a whole lot of morality to it; it‚Äôs simply an interesting character exploration.Yes. It‚Äôs a real-life story. Although there‚Äôs not a lot known about Grace, there are certain historical records and interviews with people at the time about what happened during those murders. I love real-life stories, because the behaviors are always so contradictory. It‚Äôs like ... why? Why didn‚Äôt you tell anyone? Why, when the butcher answered the door, didn‚Äôt you tell him that [James] McDermott was going to kill someone? You know? It‚Äôs funny, when Sarah Gadon and I were going through the script and making notes on the character together, we were like, ‚ÄúGrace, what were you thinking?‚Äù You think you know her, Grace. You think you have a line on her, but then there is some piece of the story that puts that out of whack. As with Simon [Jordan] during the drama. Simon is constantly being turned around and bewildered by her, and banging his head against the wall, because you can never quite get a handle on who she is.  During a TIFF masterclass this year, you told audiences that the key to eliciting a standout performance from your actors is ‚Äúentirely casting.‚Äù What was the process like casting Sarah Gadon in the role of Grace? How did you know she was the one?I had worked with her before, six or seven years ago, on a movie called ‚ÄúThe Moth Diaries,‚Äù in which she was playing 16 [years old], actually. I‚Äôd seen hundreds of people for the role I cast her in, and she actually recorded an audition for me on her computer, because she was filming overseas. As soon as I saw her, I thought, this girl is remarkable. When you meet her, she‚Äôs sort of an old soul, a very impressive person. And working with her, she‚Äôs very subtle. She does what I really like in actors, she does a lot of layers. She makes adjustments very quickly. Even as a young actress who hadn‚Äôt done that many movies, she could make these incredible subtle changes and imply a lot going on below the surface. And also, with Grace, you want someone who is very beautiful, but who has a mystery to them, which she has kind of effortlessly. You could really just watch her face for a long time. And with Edward [Holcroft], too. You know, there are these long scenes where they are just sitting in a room talking. You want to be able to linger on their faces.What kind of research did you do before filming ‚Äï in terms of reading up on the era and real-life crime?Margaret Atwood had recommended some books. She gave Sarah Polley a sort of book list, and I read one in particular ‚Äï a 19th-century woman‚Äôs account of traveling through Canada. That was really interesting on the condition of servant girls as sexual prey. It‚Äôs always interesting to read contemporary accounts that give the attitudes of the time. Margaret Atwood had done so much research into language. Usually I‚Äôm very bothered by period inaccuracies and dialogue anachronisms, but Margaret Atwood has done all the work. She is very authentic, not just in how people talked, but how they thought and behaved. You know, women thought in very different ways [in the 1800s]. Grace saw her life very differently than a woman today sees her life, or sees sexuality, religion, everything. But in terms of the kind of research I had to do, that was more with the production designer about getting the actual details of the world right. And for Sarah Gadon, she had to learn how to do all this housework! She had to learn how to sew and quilt. I didn‚Äôt want her faking, and she didn‚Äôt want to either. She‚Äôs quilting throughout so many of those conversations, so she had to be so good at it she could do it without looking. And it has to be completely natural. She spent weeks and months learning. Domestic labor is a whole story in that.Watching [Gadon] as Grace, you can actually see calluses on her hands.Right! I was with the makeup department and I was like, ‚ÄúYou have to roughen her hands.‚Äù She has beautiful hands, you know. So she did some of it herself, and then we had the makeup team roughen them up, too. You spent time at Ontario‚Äôs Kingston Penitentiary, where the real Grace Marks actually spent time during her lifetime. What was it like filming there?That was another interesting thing. When I read the script, the way that they were written, the cell was a much bigger cell. But when we went on our location scout to Kingston Penitentiary, and also to penitentiary‚Äôs museum, we saw a reproduction of a prison cell from the 19th century. It was almost a 5-foot coffin, the size of a single bed. And that‚Äôs where people would spend half their lives. I was very taken by this, by this idea that [Grace] was buried alive for all these years ‚Äï all of the prisoners were. So I had to persuade everybody, because it made it much more difficult to shoot, to make the cell smaller. She could still stand up, because we made it a foot wider. I knew it would be hard to shoot, because we couldn‚Äôt get the camera inside the room, but the production designer agreed with me ‚Äï this is important and we need to make it real. The other thing that came out from that museum, which wasn‚Äôt actually in the original script or the book, was this thing called ‚Äúthe box,‚Äù where they‚Äôd put prisoners inside this upright coffin. There‚Äôs this scene with Grace where you see her face in a little hole in the wood and she‚Äôs screaming. We just saw that box, and I asked Sarah [Polley] to write that in. It‚Äôs horrifying. It‚Äôs medieval. I mean, the rules ... you get whipped for looking or whispering or if you laugh or smile. It was barbaric, and we wanted to show that for real. Was that difficult for Sarah Gadon to perform? Did the authentic setting bring a different kind of gravity to the script?I thought it did. It was tough on her. I stepped inside that box to see what it was like and I was like, oh my God, let me out. I wouldn‚Äôt force an actress to do it, but I think most actresses who are taking it seriously want to go there and experience some of this.One of my favorite lines from the 1996 NYT review of ‚ÄúAlias Grace‚Äù reads: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing like the spectacle of female villainy brought to justice to revive the ancient, tired, apparently endless debate over whether women are by nature saintly or demonic.‚Äù This is obviously a central theme in Atwood‚Äôs book. How did you and Sarah Polley go about bringing this ‚Äúdebate‚Äù to light in your adaptation?Sarah Polley has a really great quote about this, about women conforming so much and playing to other people‚Äôs expectations of them. Of women playing different roles and playing different people in different circumstances. That‚Äôs what she‚Äôs referring to in those first few words of the script, when [Grace] says, ‚ÄúPeople think I‚Äôm a female demon. People think I‚Äôm a poor innocent victim. People think I‚Äôm this and that.‚Äù What is the essential woman? Victorian women, especially, have all these images put on them. I also loved the idea that one woman can be seen and get to portray a character in such different ways, without you knowing which is the real one. That allowed a much more complicated female character. One of the things I love about Margaret Atwood is that she‚Äôs never like, ‚ÄúMen are bad and women are good.‚Äù She‚Äôs writing about harsh social pressures and injustices that don‚Äôt always bring out the best in people. Like the relationship between Grace and Nancy [Montgomery], who are both really victims of society, both working-class girls, one of whom is pregnant and has managed to claw a little status for herself. I think Margaret Atwood has this view of women that they can become like rats in a cage ‚Äï they can turn on each other, because there‚Äôs so little safety for them. That was very truthful, about how tough social settings can bring out competitiveness and rivalries. You would like to think that women are always [supportive], but ‚Ä¶What was it like having Margaret Atwood on set? And directing her in a cameo role?Oh, it was fun. I didn‚Äôt have to do too much directing. There was a lot of panic because the schedule had gone wrong. It was like the second day of shooting, and she was waiting around in a heavy costume in 90 degree heat for hours and hours. We were like, ‚ÄúAhhhh.‚Äù But she was very good about it. And I think she was very amused, because on her trailer it said, ‚ÄúDifficult Woman.‚Äù That was her name in the [episode].How much, if at all, did she shape the adaptation? I don‚Äôt know, I‚Äôm not privy to that. Sarah showed her a lot of the drafts at every stage, I think. I think [Atwood‚Äôs] pretty hands off, but Sarah Polley was anxious that it be very faithful, so she ran a lot of it by her. Obviously the whole show is coming out in the wake of ‚ÄúHandmaid‚Äôs Tale‚Äù Season 1. If it‚Äôs possible for there to be more fandom around Margaret Atwood, now seems to be the time. Many fans saw ‚ÄúHandmaid‚Äôs Tale‚Äù as an overtly feminist show that inspired a lot of activism. Did you envision ‚ÄúAlias Grace‚Äù as an overtly feminist show?It‚Äôs feminist in the sense that it‚Äôs presenting a neglected and important piece of female history, which is the lives of female servants in a realistic way. The story of Mary Whitney happened to tens of thousands of girls. Hundreds of thousands of girls got pregnant, were raped or were seduced and abandoned, were sexual fodder for upper-class men. And that‚Äôs a really neglected part of history, you know, of what these girls‚Äô lives were like. Sarah Polley said that ‚ÄúAlias Grace‚Äù is where we come from, and ‚ÄúHandmaid‚Äôs Tale‚Äù is where we might go. It‚Äôs important politically to know where you come from in an accurate way. The same thing is happening with how we look at slavery or the Confederacy and the Civil War. It‚Äôs important for us to dig back and say, ‚ÄúWe have certain versions of the past, but are there other versions we need to be aware of?‚Äù In this case, there‚Äôs a somewhat idealized view of the country house, and the happy servants who love their masters and the masters who care for their servants. Is this true? No! Those servants were unbelievably exploited. Especially the young women, who were sexual prey to all the young men. They‚Äôd get pregnant, and that was the end of them. What was it like to get an abortion back then? Well, we‚Äôll show you. It‚Äôs not even that long ago, and that‚Äôs what our society‚Äôs grown out of. We need to remind ourselves of that. I remember when I was living in London there was this idea of returning to Victorian values. Well, those are Victorian values: child labor and young women being thrown out into the streets. That‚Äôs our history. That theme seems particularly relevant in a time when a president wants to ‚ÄúMake America Great Again.‚Äù[Laughs] A lot of the time we want to idealize the past, and that can have a political agenda behind it. People idealize the 1950s in America for the same reason ‚Äï that was a Reagan thing. Let‚Äôs return the ‚Äô50s. Well ... segregation. In terms of women‚Äôs stories, there a lot of stories that haven‚Äôt been told and perspectives that haven‚Äôt been shown. ‚ÄúAlias Grace‚Äù is not necessarily as obvious a call to action [as ‚ÄúHandmaid‚Äôs Tale], but that doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs not an important perspective.You have a history of showcasing women‚Äôs stories. You‚Äôve made films about Valerie Solanas, Bettie Page and Anna Nicole Smith. Are there any other outr√© women, who might similarly challenge notions of femininity, that you‚Äôd be interested in spotlighting in a film?Right now I‚Äôm casting for this Manson girls project. The interest there is: How do these seemingly normal, hippy girls end up doing these terrible things? What was their relationship to the cult? Why did they give over their will to this crazy leader? Part of the film is set in the early ‚Äô70s, when they are in prison, and part of the story is told from the Manson ranch. People don‚Äôt really take an interest in the girls when they tell that story. They don‚Äôt really show how it happened ‚Äï how they came to do these things. How could they? How did they? What‚Äôs the story there? There was this young feminist in her early 30s who came and gave classes to the Manson girls and wrote a book about them. I‚Äôm always interested in an untold story. And not just a straightforward story of a noble struggle, but looking at quite complicated issues of female behavior. Can‚Äôt get more complicated than the Manson girls.Taking it back a bit, you refused to cast Leonardo DiCaprio in ‚ÄúAmerican Psycho‚Äù in part because his fan base at the time consisted of teenagers, and because you‚Äôd already tapped Christian Bale. What was it like pushing back on studio executives at the time?Well, I got fired, so that‚Äôs what it was like. [Editor‚Äôs Note: Harron was eventually reinstated as director of ‚ÄúAmerican Psycho.‚Äù] Or you could say I quit, but they fired me because I didn‚Äôt want to meet with DiCaprio and I didn‚Äôt want to cast him. I‚Äôd already said I would cast Christian, who wasn‚Äôt famous at the time. Leo was. I think everyone thought I was crazy. There were two things: I thought Leo was a great actor but he wasn‚Äôt right for it. Christian was right for it. And I would never make a film if I didn‚Äôt think the lead was right. But I also knew that if they brought on the biggest star in the world for ‚ÄúAmerican Psycho,‚Äù they‚Äôd totally rewrite the script and I would lose control over the tone of it. I also thought it was totally inappropriate for this actor with a huge fan base of young girls to play this role. It just seemed wrong on so many levels. It was an advantage with Christian Bale to have someone who wasn‚Äôt as famous, because people didn‚Äôt have a lot of preconceptions. His fame didn‚Äôt get in the way.I‚Äôm very, very specific about casting and I‚Äôve been through many casting battles. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve been with a film without having a casting battle. It‚Äôs the one thing that‚Äôs make-or-break for me. I really will not do a film if I don‚Äôt think the lead is right for it. No good film was ever made if the lead was miscast. Making a film is hard enough. But Netflix was very good. They said, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to cast stars.‚Äù And I think this will make a star out of Sarah Gadon.Has it gotten any easier over the course of your career to assert yourself in that arena and have a position of power in these casting dilemmas?No, it really hasn‚Äôt. And you‚Äôd think it would.  Last question: Why isn‚Äôt ‚ÄúI Shot Andy Warhol‚Äù available to stream anywhere?I just saw Christine Vachon, the producer, at the premiere of the Todd Haynes movie [‚ÄúWonderstruck‚Äù], and she said they‚Äôre looking into getting the rights back. It‚Äôs one of those things, the company that distributed it went out of business. It breaks my heart that that film isn‚Äôt available. There are all these great actors in it. Lili Taylor. Justin Theroux‚Äôs first film! I would so love to see that film back. So, we‚Äôre working on it.This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity. ‚ÄúAlias Grace‚Äù is now streaming on Netflix.

headline: John Legend On Raising Kids In A World Filled With Gender Stereotypes
short descr: "We're being indoctrinated pretty early on," the singer said.
image_caption(s): Singer John Legend has run into gender stereotypes while raising his daughter, Luna, with Chrissy Teigen.
article: Singer John Legend is speaking out against the harm of toxic masculinity and gender stereotypes.In an interview with NBC News‚Äô Think commentary and opinion section, Legend opened up about his childhood and the ways society deems what is acceptable (toys, movies, etc.) for boys and for girls. The singer noted that he considers these harmful restrictions placed on children while raising his daughter, Luna, with Chrissy Teigen. ‚ÄúI see it even as I‚Äôm raising my daughter. The kinds of toys that are most likely given to girls versus the ones that are given to boys. The kinds of careers kids are steered into, even at a young age, that are seen as more feminine or more masculine,‚Äù he said, adding later, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre being taught very early on from movies and from the playground and all kinds of other things about how we‚Äôre supposed to interact with each other and perform our gender. We‚Äôre being indoctrinated pretty early on.‚ÄùLegend also touched on his experience as a man of color, saying he feels that black men are frequently expected to be more masculine than other men.‚ÄúSome of this expectation we put on ourselves, I think, to some extent,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs also driven from other people, as well as from the broader phenomenon of hyper-masculinity. This manifests itself in a lot of ways that can be really harmful for us and for the people we interact with, women in particular.‚ÄùThe musician credited his father with teaching him to think outside of restrictive gender norms. His dad was a manufacturing worker on an assembly line (a ‚Äústereotypically manly job,‚Äù as Legend put it), but also was open about his love for fashion and being expressive.‚ÄúI feel like we always felt like we had the permission to be artists,‚Äù Legend said. ‚ÄúIt was three boys and one girl that my dad raised, and we always felt like we had the permission to be confident in doing that kind of thing.‚ÄùIn August, Legend talked about the same topics with Cosmopolitan and explained that men aren‚Äôt encouraged to be vocal about their feelings.‚Ä≥[Men] are afraid of talking about their fears and insecurities,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre afraid of expressing emotion beyond anger, dominance, or power, and they‚Äôre afraid of getting in touch with their feminine side.‚ÄùEchoing that idea, Legend told NBC News that he encourages boys to accept their fears in order to challenge themselves and overcome them. He also advised boys who will soon become men to simply listen.‚ÄúWell, I think part of it is to learn, to listen, to pay attention to other people and not only learn from books and from outside media, but also listen to your classmates,‚Äù Legend said. ‚ÄúListen to women. Listen to people who are different from you and develop a sense of empathy for the things that they‚Äôre going through. I think we should all be humble and we should all listen to each other and learn from each other.‚ÄùRead Legend‚Äôs interview in full on NBC News‚Äô Think section.

headline: CMA Lifts Award Show Press Restrictions On Guns, Politics After Outcry (UPDATE)
short descr: The initial guidelines warned that reporters asking about "gun rights, political affiliations or topics of the like‚Äù could get the boot.
image_caption(s): Brad Paisley and Carrie Underwood appear onstage at the 2016 CMA Awards.
article: UPDATE: 1:03 p.m. ‚Äî The Country Music Association released a statement Friday lifting its previous reporter restrictions. ‚ÄúCMA apologizes for the recently distributed restrictions in the CMA Awards media guidelines, which have since been lifted,‚Äù the statement read. ‚ÄúThe sentiment was not to infringe and was created with the best of intentions to honor and celebrate Country Music.‚ÄùPREVIOUSLY:A list of guidelines released by the Country Music Association for the upcoming CMA Awards urges reporters to stay away from certain topics, like guns and politics, or face getting kicked out. By accepting a media credential, reporters agree to ‚Äúrefrain from focusing [coverage on] ... gun rights, political affiliations or topics of the like‚Äù to make attendees ‚Äúfeel comfortable‚Äù at the CMA Awards, taking place Nov. 8 at the Bridgestone Arena in Nashville.The rule was set following the Las Vegas shooting at the Route 91 Harvest Festival last month during a Jason Aldean performance, which left almost 60 people dead and hundreds injured, according to the media guidelines release.In light of recent events, and out of respect for the artists directly or indirectly involved, please refrain from focusing your coverage of the CMA Awards Red Carpet and Backstage Media Center on the Las Vegas tragedy, gun rights, political affiliations or topics of the like. It‚Äôs vital, more so this year than in year‚Äôs past due to the sensitivities at hand, that the CMA Awards be a celebration of Country Music and the artists that make this genre so great. It‚Äôs an evening to honor the outstanding achievements in Country Music of the previous year and we want everyone to feel comfortable talking to press about this exciting time. If you are reported as straying from these guidelines, your credential will be reviewed and potentially revoked via security escort. We appreciate your cooperation in advance. If you have any concerns on your coverage plans, please reach out to the CMA Communications team in advance so we can be a great partner as we celebrate ‚ÄúThe 51st Annual CMA Awards.‚Äù Currently, the press list includes journalists from major outlets, including ABC, NBC, The Los Angeles Times, Associated Press and USA Today. Rolling Stone spoke with Brad Paisley, who is once again set to host this year‚Äôs awards show alongside Carrie Underwood, about taking the stage after the Las Vegas massacre and how to properly handle it. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not going to ignore it, but we‚Äôre not going to also dwell on that,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe have to make sure we honor those we‚Äôve lost, but we also [have to] celebrate this music, which lives on, and do a good job having the heart we need to have on that night. And also the theme of the show this year is very much about unity and coming together as a format.‚ÄùOn Friday, Paisely tweeted his disapproval of the guidelines. A rep for the Country Music Association did not immediately respond to HuffPost‚Äôs request for comment.

headline: Ralph Northam Slams ‚ÄòMuslim Ban‚Äô At Mosque, Insists He‚Äôs Running A Positive Campaign
short descr: The Virginia Democrat accused his GOP opponent Ed Gillespie of "trying to scare people."
image_caption(s): Virginia Democratic gubernatorial candidate Ralph Northam addresses worshippers at a mosque after Friday prayers.
article: STERLING, Va. ‚Äï Democrat Ralph Northam visited a mosque in northern Virginia on Friday, urging worshippers there to vote in next week‚Äôs gubernatorial election to reject the ‚Äúhatred and bigotry‚Äù coming from Washington, D.C.‚ÄúI want to remind all of you that the U.S. is a country of immigrants,‚Äù Northam, Virginia‚Äôs lieutenant governor, told the men, women and children attending Friday prayers at the All Dulles Area Muslim Society. ‚ÄúWe welcome people to this country. And the travel ban, the Muslim ban, is un-American, is unacceptable.‚ÄùAll Dulles Area Muslim Society is one of the largest mosques in the United States. It regularly hosts political candidates, but it does not endorse them. Ed Gillespie, Northam‚Äôs Republican opponent, also stopped by to speak there this year.This week, two federal judges struck down the latest iteration of President Donald Trump‚Äôs travel ban, which restricts people from a handful of mostly Muslim-majority countries from entering the U.S. They said the ban appeared to be a veiled, unconstitutional attempt to bar Muslims based on their religion ‚Äï a proposal Trump explicitly called for during last year‚Äôs presidential campaign.In his brief remarks on Friday, Northam, who is a pediatrician, stressed the need to give kids a quality education and affordable health care. He also noted that he had protested against Trump‚Äôs first travel ban in February at nearby Dulles International Airport.Northam‚Äôs introductory speaker was far more blunt about the ban.Robert Maro, an activist who stood alongside the lieutenant governor and several Virginia House delegates, asked worshippers in the prayer room to raise their hands if they opposed the idea of banning Muslims coming into the U.S. A few arms went up, but most of the room stayed seated, listening or engaged in prayer.‚ÄúI see people who don‚Äôt have their hands raised. Do you not oppose that?‚Äù Maro asked.‚ÄúWho thinks it‚Äôs OK to lie?‚Äù he tried again.Northam was received warmly at the event, shaking hands and greeting mosque leaders who thanked him for coming. It was apparent, however, that some attendees on Friday were showing signs of election fatigue due to the steady stream of candidates who had addressed the Muslim community there in recent weeks.‚ÄúThey‚Äôre getting a little bit jaded, so this is an idea of waking them up,‚Äù Maro said later of his attempt to warm up the crowd. Even as he was busy denouncing Trump for his immigration-related executive actions, Northam faced questions about his own record on immigration on Friday. Democracy for America, a major national progressive group, denounced Northam‚Äôs campaign as ‚Äúgutless‚Äù and ‚Äúracist‚Äù this week after Northam said he would sign a bill banning so-called ‚Äúsanctuary cities,‚Äù or municipalities that limit their cooperation with federal immigration authorities, should any Virginia locality pursue that status in the future.  The broadside from Democracy for America, which had never supported Northam‚Äôs campaign, unleashed an intraparty squabble that threatened his campaign‚Äôs momentum just days before Tuesday‚Äôs election.Speaking with HuffPost after the event, Northam insisted that ‚Äúnothing has changed with my stance on sanctuary cities.‚ÄùNortham also continued to distance himself from a controversial ad run by a Latino Democratic group that has since been taken off the air. The ad showed young children of color fleeing a white man in a pickup truck with a Confederate flag and a Gillespie bumper sticker. The Washington Post editorial board, which endorsed Northam, said the ad ‚Äúhad no place‚Äù in the race.‚ÄúIt was their choice to promote that ad. That is not an ad that I would have run,‚Äù Northam told HuffPost.Northam dodged a question, however, over whether he explicitly denounced the ad, maintaining only that he would not have made the decision to put it on air.‚ÄúWe‚Äôre running a positive campaign,‚Äù Northam insisted. ‚Äú[Gillespie] is running a campaign that‚Äôs trying to scare people, that‚Äôs trying to promote fear mongering, the hatred and bigotry.‚Äù

headline: Trump Previews Asia Trip With Foreboding Message For Japan
short descr: "They should be worried," he said about the North Korean threat.
image_caption(s): Shinzo Abe, Japan's prime minister, and U.S. President Donald Trump talked during the United Nations General Assembly in New York City in September. They will see each other again during Trump's trip to Asia.
article: President Donald Trump will depart on his longest overseas trip yet on Friday, embarking on a 12-day visit to Japan, South Korea, China, Vietnam and the Philippines following a brief stop in Hawaii. Instead of appeasing the Asian allies he was slated to visit, or previewing the discussions he planned to have, he shot Japan a warning about the North Korean nuclear threat.‚ÄúOf course they‚Äôre worried,‚Äù he told Fox News‚Äô Laura Ingraham on Thursday when she prodded him about Japan, which is located only about 650 miles from the rogue regime. ‚ÄúThey should be worried. You know, they‚Äôre very close to North Korea.‚ÄùJapan is a U.S. ally and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is ‚Äúa very good friend‚Äù of his, Trump continued. It‚Äôs a ‚Äúwarrior nation,‚Äù he warned, ‚Äúand I tell everyone else that, listen, you‚Äôre going to have yourself a big problem with Japan pretty soon if you allow this to continue with North Korea.‚ÄùHe then struck a more positive tone, praising the close relationship he‚Äôs developed with Chinese leader Xi Jinping, who has been, per Trump, ‚Äúpretty terrific.‚ÄùThe Trump administration has taken an unprecedented tack on dealing with the North Korean nuclear threat, demanding that China share the burden and leverage its influence over the rogue nation. Trump‚Äôs hopeful, he said, that the issue can be solved.‚ÄúI think a lot of good things are going to happen. I think it‚Äôs a very important trip. I think this is one of the more important trips that a president has made.‚ÄùThe administration plans to ask other Asian allies to ‚Äúdo more‚Äù during the trip, national security adviser H.R. McMaster told reporters Thursday.Trump has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea‚Äôs nuclear prowess continues to grow, going as far in a September speech as claiming he would ‚Äútotally destroy‚Äù the country. The president also signed an executive order expanding sanctions that same month.Trump ‚Äúwill remind friend and foe alike that the United States stands ready to defend itself and our allies using the full range of our capabilities,‚Äù McMaster said.But he did note the administration is willing to ‚Äúbe a little patient here for at least a few months to see what more we and others can do.‚ÄùHow much the Chinese are prepared to do on Trump‚Äôs behalf is up for debate. While China ‚Äï one of North Korea‚Äôs few allies and trade partners ‚Äï has imposed United Nations Security Council sanctions, it has also asked Trump to ‚Äúcool it‚Äù with the inflammatory rhetoric and urged a diplomatic approach instead.No president has spent this much time in Asia on one trip since President George H.W. Bush in the early 1990s, Reuters said.
